Authors: Soon G.-L., Samsudin N.-H., Lim D.
Title: Evaluating the Effect of Multiple Filters in Automatic Language Identification without Lexical Knowledge
Source title: International Journal of Advanced Computer Science and Applications
Affiliations: Hardware Building Block (HWBB) Motorola Solution (Malaysia), Sdn Bhd Penang, Malaysia; School of Computer Sciences, Universiti Sains Malaysia, Penang, Malaysia; PCR Software Architecture Group, Motorola Solution (Malaysia), Sdn Bhd Penang, Malaysia
Authors with affiliations: Soon, G.-L., Hardware Building Block (HWBB) Motorola Solution (Malaysia), Sdn Bhd Penang, Malaysia; Samsudin, N.-H., School of Computer Sciences, Universiti Sains Malaysia, Penang, Malaysia; Lim, D., PCR Software Architecture Group, Motorola Solution (Malaysia), Sdn Bhd Penang, Malaysia
Abstract: The classical language identification architecture would require a collection of languages independent text and speech information for training by the system before it can identify the languages correctly. This paper also address language identification framework however with data has been downsized considerably from general language identification architecture. The system goal is to identify the type of language being spoken to the system based on a series of trained speech with sound file features and without any language text data or lexical knowledge of the spoken language. The system is also expected to be able to be deployed in mobile platform in future. This paper is specifically about measuring the performance optimisation of audio filters on a CNN model integration for the language identification system. There are several metric to gauge the performance identification system for a classification problem. Precision, recall and F1 Scores is presented for the performance evaluation with different combination of filters together with CNN model as the framework of the language identification system. The goal is not to get the best filter for noise, instead to identify the filter that is a good fit to develop language model with environmental noise for a robust language identification system. Our experiments manage to identify the best combination of filters to increase the accuracy of language identification using short speech. This resulting us to modify our pre-processing phase in the overall language identification system. © 2020 Science and Information Organization. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Language identification; Minimal language data; Minimal lexical information; Optimal performance; Speech filters; Speech recognition

Authors: Lim Y.Q., Lim C.M., Gan K.H., Samsudin N.H.
Title: Text Sentiment Analysis on Twitter to Identify Positive or Negative Context in Addressing Inept Regulations on Social Media Platform
Source title: ISCAIE 2020 - IEEE 10th Symposium on Computer Applications and Industrial Electronics
Affiliations: School of Computer Sciences, Universiti Sains Malaysia, Pulau Pinang, Malaysia
Authors with affiliations: Lim, Y.Q., School of Computer Sciences, Universiti Sains Malaysia, Pulau Pinang, Malaysia; Lim, C.M., School of Computer Sciences, Universiti Sains Malaysia, Pulau Pinang, Malaysia; Gan, K.H., School of Computer Sciences, Universiti Sains Malaysia, Pulau Pinang, Malaysia; Samsudin, N.H., School of Computer Sciences, Universiti Sains Malaysia, Pulau Pinang, Malaysia
Abstract: The growth of social media in this digital era is staggering. People take to this new-found platform to expression their views and idea, resulting a growing number of problems in the social media platform due to regulatory bodies struggled to keep up with the growth. In this paper, we will explore the problems caused by the slack and irresponsible users of social media, and how text sentiment analysis on Twitter can be used to identify the problem, and help in drafting regulations to produce a better social media platform ecosystem. © 2020 IEEE.
Author Keywords: ELMO; sentiment analysis; social media; TF-IDF; Twitter; Word2vec
Index Keywords: Industrial electronics; Sentiment analysis; Digital era; Regulatory bodies; Social media; Social media platforms; Social networking (online)

Authors: Kong S.H., Tan L.M., Gan K.H., Samsudin N.H.
Title: Fake News Detection using Deep Learning
Source title: ISCAIE 2020 - IEEE 10th Symposium on Computer Applications and Industrial Electronics
Affiliations: School of Computer Sciences, Universiti Sains Malaysia, Pulau Pinang, Malaysia
Authors with affiliations: Kong, S.H., School of Computer Sciences, Universiti Sains Malaysia, Pulau Pinang, Malaysia; Tan, L.M., School of Computer Sciences, Universiti Sains Malaysia, Pulau Pinang, Malaysia; Gan, K.H., School of Computer Sciences, Universiti Sains Malaysia, Pulau Pinang, Malaysia; Samsudin, N.H., School of Computer Sciences, Universiti Sains Malaysia, Pulau Pinang, Malaysia
Abstract: FAKE news has proliferated to a big crowd than before in this digital era, the main factor derives from the rise of social media and direct messaging platform. Techniques of fake news stories detection ingenious, varied, and exciting. This study aims to apply natural language processing (NLP) techniques for text analytics and train deep learning models for detecting fake news based on news title or news content. Solution proposed in this study aims to be applied in real-world social media and eliminate the bad experience for user to receive misleading stories that come from non-reputable source. For NLP techniques, text preprocessing such as regular expression, tokenization, lemmatization and stop words removal are used before vectorizing them into N-gram vectors or sequence vectors using terms frequency inverse document frequency (TF-IDF) or one-hot encoding respectively. Then, TensorFlow is chosen as the framework to be used with built in Keras deep learning libraries that is having a large community and number of commits on Tensorflow GitHub repository that can be enough to build deep learning neural network models. Results from the models are showing that models trained with news content can achieve better performance with computation time being sacrificed while models trained with news title require less computation time to achieve good performance. Also, overall performance of models fed with N-gram vectors are slightly better than models fed with sequence vectors. © 2020 IEEE.
Author Keywords: deep learning; Fake news; Keras; natural language processing; neural network; TensorFlow
Index Keywords: Computational linguistics; Industrial electronics; Learning systems; Natural language processing systems; Social networking (online); State assignment; Text processing; User experience; Vectors; Computation time; Inverse Document Frequency; Learning models; Learning neural networks; NAtural language processing; Nlp techniques; Regular expressions; Text preprocessing; Deep learning

Title: Rapid Heteronym Disambiguation for Text-to-Speech System
Source title: ICRAIE 2019 - 4th International Conference and Workshops on Recent Advances and Innovations in Engineering: Thriving Technologies
Affiliations: Universiti Sains Malaysia, School of Computer Sciences, Penang, Malaysia
Authors with affiliations: Samsudin, N.-H., Universiti Sains Malaysia, School of Computer Sciences, Penang, Malaysia; Rahim, L.N., Universiti Sains Malaysia, School of Computer Sciences, Penang, Malaysia
Abstract: This paper is about the text analysis component for heteronym words for Malay Text-to-Speech (TTS) system. Heteronym is a homograph words which the meaning and the pronunciation differ according to the semantic of the sentence. There is only 12 unique heteronym in Malay. However, these words can be expanded depending on the morphology of the sentence. Malay language is also very rich with prefix and suffixes. Thus, one word can be expanded either to two unique words or more. For the list of 12 unique pair of words, we can expand the list to 98 unique words. Thus, there are greater variation possibility of enunciating a heteronym words. This research showed the importance of a study on heteronym words specifically in TTS case as well as what would be the best approach of handling heteronym ambiguity when only the sampled data is available but not tagged data of a particular target language. © 2019 IEEE.
Author Keywords: expandable corpora; heteronym; homograph disambiguation; limited resource; text-to-speech
Index Keywords: Engineering; Industrial engineering; Malay languages; Malay texts; Sampled data; Tagged data; Target language; Text analysis; Text-to-speech system; Unique word; Semantics

Title: Building text-to-speech systems for resource poor languages
Source title: Proceedings of the 8th International Conference on Language Resources and Evaluation, LREC 2012
Affiliations: School of Computer Science, University of Birmingham, Birmingham, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Samsudin, N.-H., School of Computer Science, University of Birmingham, Birmingham, United Kingdom; Lee, M., School of Computer Science, University of Birmingham, Birmingham, United Kingdom
Abstract: This paper describes research on building text-to-speech synthesis systems (TTS) for resource poor languages using available resources from other languages and describes our general approach to building cross-linguistic polyglot TTS. Our approach involves three main steps: language clustering, grapheme to phoneme mapping and prosody modelling. We have tested the mapping of phonemes from German to English and from Indonesian to Spanish. We have also constructed three prosody representations for different language characteristics. For evaluation we have developed an English TTS based on German data, and a Spanish TTS based on Indonesian data and compared their performance against pre-existing monolingual TTSs. Since our motivation is to develop speech synthesis for resource poor languages, we have also developed three TTS for Iban, an Austronesian language with practically no available language resources, using Malay, Indonesian and Spanish resources.
Author Keywords: Multilinguality; Polyglot speech synthesis; Resource adaptation; TTS
Index Keywords: Mapping; Speech synthesis; Austronesian languages; Grapheme to phonemes; Language resources; Multilinguality; Polyglot speech synthesis; Resource adaptation; Text-to-speech synthesis system; Text-to-speech system; Modeling languages

Title: Constructing a reusable linguistic resource for a polyglot speech synthesis
Source title: AISB 2011: Learning Language Models from Multilingual Corpora
Authors with affiliations: Samsudin, N.-H., University of Birmingham, United Kingdom; Lee, M., University of Birmingham, United Kingdom
Abstract: This paper is about constructing sharable linguistic information to be used across languages for a Text-to-Speech (TTS) system. The data is obtained from existing resources. The focus of the paper is the phonetic and linguistic aspects. A monolingual TTS architecture is introduced with descriptions on each stage of processing. A multilingual TTS architecture is also introduced. Language dependent and language independent information required in the general TTS engine is described. Finally we will propose layer of communication between the pooled language information and a TTS engine in order to make it available for information reuse where possible for different languages.
Index Keywords: Information reuse; Language informations; Linguistic information; Linguistic resources; Text-to-speech system; Artificial intelligence; Computational linguistics; Speech synthesis

Authors: Samsudin N.-H., Tang Enya K., Chuah K.
Title: Comparison of orthographically and phonologically written glides for malay speech synthesis
Source title: 2005 1st International Conference on Computers, Communications and Signal Processing with Special Track on Biomedical Engineering, CCSP 2005
Affiliations: Computer-Aided Translation Unit (UTMK), School of Computer Sciences, University Sains Malaysia, Penang, Malaysia
Authors with affiliations: Samsudin, N.-H., Computer-Aided Translation Unit (UTMK), School of Computer Sciences, University Sains Malaysia, Penang, Malaysia; Tang Enya, K., Computer-Aided Translation Unit (UTMK), School of Computer Sciences, University Sains Malaysia, Penang, Malaysia; Chuah, K., Computer-Aided Translation Unit (UTMK), School of Computer Sciences, University Sains Malaysia, Penang, Malaysia
Abstract: This paper reports our observation on comparison between a written form of text (orthographic) and transformed text because of spelling to pronunciation rules (phonological). This is to show whether there is any difference in pronouncing these two types of spelling form in Malay. It is also important to know that Malay is a non-tonal language. Thus, this study will not be affected by semantic of a word. This comparison is important to determine whether it is necessary to have a parameter to represent different prominence in pronunciation between these two situations in our unit selection speech corpus. © 2005 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Glides formation / insertion; Orthographic form; Phonological form; Speech synthesis; Unit selection
Index Keywords: Glides formation / insertion; Non-tonal languages; Orthographic form; Phonological form; Speech corpora; Unit selection; Biomedical engineering; Signal processing; Speech synthesis
